Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Refractory Cleavage Sites to Elucidate Type IIS Restriction Endonuclease Mechanisms
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Professor Michael Van Dyke from Kennesaw State University (KSU) to investigate an enzymes called type IIS restriction endonucleases that cleaves deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) in specific places. Restriction endonucleases are critical tools in biotechnology, allowing investigators to make specific fragments of DNA. The fragments can be recombined to create new DNA sequences, otherwise known as recombinant DNA. Type IIS restriction endonucleases, recognize specific DNA sequences, but then cleave DNA at fixed distances away from them. Previous work reported that this cleavage occurred without any regard to the specific sequence (sequence specificity). However, sequences have now been identified that are completely resistant to this cleavage. This project investigates why certain DNA sequences are unable to be cleaved by type IIS restriction endonucleases, which may impact their use in biotechnology. Also, this research incorporates a mix of undergraduate and Master's graduate students, providing them with training in the biochemistry of nucleic acids and associated enzymes. Professor Van Dyke mentors graduate school-oriented undergraduate students and maintenance of the nascent Sequencing Core Facility at KSU. 
 
This research project is undertaken to mechanistically determine why specific DNA sequences are refractory to the type IIS restriction endonuclease FokI. Cleavage-resistant sequences identified through the combinatorial approach Restriction Endonuclease Protection, Selection, and Amplification are sequenced and resistant motifs identified for Motif Elicitation analysis. These sequences are independently validated using an internally controlled Restriction Endonuclease Protection Assay to characterize observed cleavage resistance as a function of time, temperature, and concentration. Stopped-flow spectroscopy studies are then performed using Förster resonance energy transfer (FRET) to dissect individual steps during the process of DNA cleavage by FokI and to determine those affected by the identified cleavage-resistant sequences. Information from this study may provide a better mechanistic understanding of DNA recognition and cleavage by IIS restriction endonucleases, with potential applicability to other DNA cleavage/modification systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Kennesaw State University received an award to support investigations into Type II restriction endonucleases (IISREs), enzymes that cleave DNA at specific locations without regard to their sequence. This seeming contradiction lends these proteins to be powerful tools in biotechnology, with uses ranging from Golden Gate cloning to autonomous biomolecular computing. These applications rely on IISREs cleaving all target DNAs with equal efficiency. Like all tools, understanding their limitations is critically essential for their practical application.

 

Using a unique iterative selection method, Restriction Endonuclease Protection, Selection and Amplification (REPSA), massively parallel semiconductor sequencing, and MEME motif discovery, we determined two consensus sequences for cleavage resistance by the archetype IISRE FokI. In the first, FokI cleavage is inhibited by an intervening oligo-T sequence. In the second, FokI cleavage is completely abolished by two FokI molecules positioned head-to-head. Parameters influencing this cleavage inhibition, including enzyme and substrate concentrations, time, and temperature, were fully explored. Sequence effects were determined through a systematic mutational analysis. These studies provided us with a better understanding of the mechanisms underlying IISRE cleavage inhibition. Bottom line, the IISRE FokI does not cleave all DNAs equally, which has definite implications for its use in many roles.

 

To explore the generality of cleavage inhibition, we investigated whether additional IISREs behaved like FokI. Following a survey, we identified another IISRE, BsmFI, that inhibits its cleavage when positioned in a head-to-head orientation. BsmFI is isolated from the organism, Bacillus stearothermophilus, which lives at extremely high temperatures (65 ?C). Thus, both thermophilic and mesothermic (37 ?C) IISREs can exhibit cleavage inhibition for particular sequences.

 

Research performed for this project has been part of the education of thirteen undergraduate and five graduate students at Kennesaw State University. Notably, thirteen were female, three international, and seven minorities underrepresented in the sciences. These students gained knowledge in the enzymology of DNA-modifying proteins and modern methods for their analysis through their participation. Several have presented their research in either local or regional symposia, and some will have their first publications as a result. Of those who have graduated, seven have gone on to graduate studies or finding employment in STEM careers.

 

This project has led to developing a modular curriculum in our undergraduate research courses CHEM 2050 Introduction to Directed Research and CHEM 4100 Directed Applied Research. These courses provide both hands-on experience in advanced biochemistry/molecular biology techniques and instrumentation and an exposure into the mindset of hypothesis-based research. Through this, students learn critical data analysis and problem-solving skills. They also have an opportunity to practice their oral and written communication skills in scientific venues. These courses will be important parts of the training of future students, and ultimately, STEM researchers throughout the United States and beyond.

 

As part of our research, we have developed many techniques for studying proteins and nucleic acids specifically designed to be suitable for undergraduate researchers' investigations (i.e., safe, simple, low-cost). Several of these have been published at Protocols.io and are highly viewed by the scientific community (see https://www.protocols.io/researchers/michael-van-dyke/publications). We anticipate these will have a significant future impact on several aspects of biochemistry and molecular biology education and research, especially if they are undertaken in a primarily undergraduate environment.
